sub_title: Assistant Professor at Maastricht University | Arterial stiffness researcher | Bridging engineering and medicine | Yale postdoctoral alumnus
summary:
I am a multidisciplinary researcher in the field of arterial biomechanics, aiming to integrate clinical and engineering research. I am committed to disentangling the problem of arterial stiffening by combining pre-clinical and clinical research. Combining state-of-the-art measurement techniques — computer controlled bi-axial mechanical testing; high-frequency ultrasound; two-photon microscopy; arterial applanation tonometry; and echo wall tracking — with constitutive computer modelling enables me to mechanically understand the changes occurring in the ageing artery wall.

When I have some time off, I am a passionate traveller, whether it be for hiking, skiing, or simply exploring the world.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor at Maastricht University | Arterial stiffness researcher | Bridging engineering and medicine | Yale postdoctoral alumnus

projects.title: Scientific collaborations
projects.description:
Besides my positions listed under "Experience", I maintain close collaborations with the following researchers:
- Dr. Marcos Latorre, Polytechnic University of Valencia, Valencia, Spain. I’m working with Dr. Latorre on the growth and remodelling-based interpretation of biomechanical data.
- Dr. Jason Au, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada. Dr. Au is an expert on longitudinal motion of the artery wall.
- Dr. Giacomo Pucci, University of Perugia, Terni University Hospital, Perugia, Italy. Dr. Pucci is a leading researcher into the relationship between arterial stiffness and blood pressure.
- Prof. Pierre Boutouyrie, European Georges Pompidou Hospital, Paris, France. Prof. Boutouyrie is an MD specialised in the fields of arterial stiffness and pharmacology.
- Dr. Rosa Maria Bruno, University of Pisa, Italy and European Georges Pompidou Hospital, Paris, France. Dr. Bruno is specialised in the fields of flow-mediated dilation (endothelial function) and arterial stiffness. In addition, she leads the CARTESIAN study into arterial stiffness changes in COVID-19 patients.
- Dr. Mohsen Agharazii, Université Laval, Quebec, Canada. Dr. Agharazii is a nephrologist and a clinician-scientist, focussing on large artery remodelling.
- Prof. Ingrid Tonhajzerova and Dr. Michal Mestanik, Biomedical Center Martin, Division Neurosciences, Jessenius Faculty of Medicine in Martin, Comenius University in Bratislava. Drs. Tonhajzerova and Mestanik are experts conducting human physiological studies.
- Dr. Stella Daskalopoulou and Ms. Alexandra Cooke MSc. Both are experts in Exercise Experimental Medicine at McGill University, Montréal, Quebec, Canada.
- Dr. Julio Chirinos, Perelman School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, PA, United States. Dr. Chirinos is at the forefront of arterial stiffness research in the United States.

profile_positions.description:
STIFF VESSELS APPROACHED IN A FLEXIBLE WAY - 
ADVANCING QUANTIFICATION AND INTERPRETATION OF ARTERIAL STIFFNESS

During my PhD, I have applied mechanical principles to clinically measurable stiffness measures, but also have used clinical measurements to characterise arterial mechanics in complex constitutive computer models.
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate: Stiff vessels approached in a flexible way

profile_positions.description: In this project, I started studying the role of the different wall components on the biomechanical behaviour of the artery wall. I continued this work in my PhD project (see above).

company.name: Maastricht University, Department of Biomedical Engineering

profile_positions.description: Regulation of cerebral blood flow (i.e., blood flow to the brain) is based on a variety of different control mechanisms. Although the existence of these mechanisms has been shown, their quantitative regulatory role remains largely unknown. The cerebral regulatory system expresses two regulatory properties: cerebral autoregulation and neurovascular coupling. Cerebral autoregulation ensures that, while mean arterial blood pressure changes, cerebral blood flow is maintained at a constant, demand-based level. Neurovascular coupling increases cerebral blood flow with increased brain activity. I aim to develop a mathematical model of cerebral blood flow regulation based on physiological mechanisms to gain insight in how these mechanisms contribute to cerebral blood flow regulation. In order to do so, I performed measurements on healthy volunteers using transcranial Doppler ultrasonography and finger plethysmography. In these measurements, autoregulation is stimulated using repeated squat-stand manoeuvres whereas neurovascular coupling is evoked by visual stimulation.
profile_positions.title: MSc graduation project: Development and verification of a cerebral blood flow regulation model
